div.head: THE NEBRASKANETTE
Teachers College High School University of Nebraska
Lincoln, Nebraska
div.label: STAFF

div.head: PREFACE
div.p:
fancy "L"Last year a new idea was worked out
whereby the longer literary efforts of
the students could be published. The
result was a magazine edition of the
Nebraskanette and it proved successful
enough to be worth trying again. We
hope you enjoy it and that in future
years more and better magazines will be
printed.

div.head: STAGEFRIGHT
div.p:
fancy "M"My first appearance in public was a trying or-
deal. I was playing in a piano recital and there
were about fifty other students beside myself who
were also playing in the recital. I was eleven
years old and thoroughly frightened. I was to
play a waltz and a march and was about the fortieth
student to play in the program.

Seeing the big audience made me shudder in my
tracks and I was in a terrible suspense waiting
for my turn to play. When my turn finally came, I
slowly and quite unsteadily, to be sure, made my
way across the stage to the piano. My teeth were
chattering and suddenly my fingers became very
stiff! Everyone was watching me, so I tried to
begin to play. Somehow I finished the waltz and
was waiting for the audience to become quiet in
order that I could finish and run off the stage
from all these frightening people. I played
the march as if I were chasing a fire engine to a
fire, and almost fell, because I was in such a
hurry to leave the stage.

My next public appearance came when I learned
how to play the violin and joined the Irving Junior
High School orchestra. I also played in the Lin-
coln High School Summer "A" orchestra.

The most embarassingembarrassing situation arose while I
was playing in a concert at Northeast High School.
It happened just before curtain time. I broke a
violin string and was unable to fix it myself. Our
conductor finally fixed it for me delaying the pro-
gram about a half minute.

My second piano recital was a little more like
recitals ought to be. However, I was so scared my
hands became cold, and I could not move my fingers.
The agony and suspense of waiting for my turn to
play in the program was dreadful. I was contin-
uously trying to tell myself that I might profit
by listening to the others play. The main diffi-
culty was sitting still without making any noises
and not being conspicuous. I was supposed to be
enjoying the music! My main accomplishment of
this recital was that there was a more distinct
difference between my march and other number.

Playing at home also presets its problems. I
do not know of anyone who likes to listen to any-
one practice piano. This is particularly true at
our house. I am terribly annoyed when I know that
other people are listening to me practice and wat-
ching my play. The only audience that does not
other me is- - -Mom. She usually sits and knits
while she listens to me play. She criticizes my
playing, but it does not seem to bother me.

Last year I played violin at Teachers College
High School. We called our small class of three
students a "String Trio." Because of the size of
the class, we played solos almost every day, and I
was gradually beginning to lose some of my stage-
fright.

No matter how often I play in public, I always
have at least a mild case of- - - - - - - - - -Stagefright.

div.head: WILLA CATHER
div.p:
fancy "I"I have read a lot of Willa Cather's books and
find them interesting. She tells in a way of
understanding in all her books and they never
get boring if you like peoneerpioneerstories.

Here are some of her books: O Pioneers. This
story which Willa Cather has written is particu-
larly written for herself about Bohemians and
ScandenaviansScandinavians, neighbors to each other. Read the
book.

The Song of the Lark. This story is of an Am-
erican opera singer and her childhood in the Colo-
rado desert and her early struggle in Chicago, her
romantic adventures among the cliff dwellers' ruins
in Arizona, her splendid triumph on the operatic
stage.

My Antonia is another good story. It is packed
with the feeling of the country. A scant para-
graph sets you out on the plain and the breath of
the wind never leaves your face.

Death Comes for the Archbishop. This book is
mainly about the Archbishop and all his trouble.
It is a good story for people who like traveling.
Other Stories:
Short Stories:

div.head: MY CHRISTMAS MEMORIES
div.p:
fancy "S"Some of the happiest memories of my childhood
are centered around Christmas time. We always
have a Christmas tree with gifts when we get up
Christmas morning.

My mother recalls one Christmas when she sent
my brothers and me back to bed four times during
the night to finally have us awake the whole
household about five a.m. I remember the high-
light for me on this particular Christmas was a
red wagon.

After eating breakfast and examining our gifts
left by Santa, we always went to my grandmother's
house for a noon-time Christmas dinner of roast
turkey, goose, or duck with cranberries and dress-
ing, mince and pumpkin pie, fruit cake made by
Grandmother, and everything in the way of food any
one can imagine. All my cousins, brothers, and
sisters, and even the grownups, ate until they
were practically unconscious.

Hand-drawn little boy playing with a train. Then we op-ened gifts which
the relatives always exchanged.
Each year the procedure was
the same. Then all the young
folks went out sleigh riding,
skating, or play-ing games while
the women washed the dishes after
dinner.

Since we are now older, we
celebrate Christ-mas in our own
home, often with a lot of aunts, uncles, and cous-
ins helping us.

This will be the first Christmas any member of
our family of ten has had to be away from home,
but I know my brother, who is away, will have a
lot of pleasant memories of past Christmases. We
all hope he will be home again by next Christmas.

lg.l: I hate to board a bus,
Cause everyone's in such a fuss.
They push, they joggle and jar,
One man yells, "I'm back too far."
And the woman with bundles piled high,
Is a menace to all near by.
The capacity is thirty or more,
But some are sittin' on the floor.
When the door opens a few fall out
And finally the man that's stout
Gets off, and all is well,
Why can't I have a car like you.

div.head: BOYS WHO SMOKE
div.p:
fancy "A"All races have found something to smoke. People
down through the ages have been smoking powdered
herbs, grasses, and medical powders. Indians were
the first to smoke tobacco. They taught the colo-
nists how to raise and use it.

Young people have been given a healthy body and
talents. When they take to smoking they are wast-
ing health, talent, and money. Young people are
more susceptible to injuries from smoking than are
adults. Those who smoke never live as long as
those who do not. Smoking shortens their wind and
causes a cough. It also breaks down their health.
The latter isn't something money can buy after it
is lost.

Boys can't impress other people by smoking.
Anyone can learn to smoke- - even a five year old.
It's not an art, as some boys would like us to
believe.

To my way of thinking there are three distinct
types of youthful smokers:
Those who say:

"I'm tough, see? I'm fifteen years old, but
you think I look twenty-one?"

Number two: The type who act like Humphrey
Bogart and take long drags at their cigarettes and
manufacture a tough look in their eyes.

Number three: They type who act as if they have
been smoking all their lives, when in reality only
lately has it become a habit.

They don't fool us a bit and it doesn't make
them look more manly. Besides, who wants to be
9
The Nebraskanette 10
near a boy who smells like a smoke stack. They
look rather silly with a cigarette dangling out of
the corner of their mouth. Anyway we prefer the
wholesome Van Johnson type. We don't like to see
boys start bad habits which will last them all
their lives.

div.head: YOUTH WEEK
JAN. 27-FEB.4, 1946
div.p: fancy "T"Theme: Mold the World Through Daily Christian Living.

Youth Week is observed by all young people of
the Protestant Churches in North America and is
sponsored by the United Christian Youth Movement.
During this week many activities are carried out
in the local churches and schools. Some of the
activities to take place in Lincoln include serv-
ices in the churches given by the young people on
Sunday, January 27, a city-wide party that will be
held at the First Plymouth Congregational Church
on February 1, and a city-wide rally to be held
February 3, at one of the local churches.

Youth Week began more than thirty years ago in
the annual celebration of the birthday of Christ-
ian Endeavor, February 2. With the growth of the
United Christian Youth Movement (continent wide,
interdenominational, representing 10,000,000 Prot-
estant young people) there grew a need for a
united observance.

Youth Week is a United Effort to Win Youth for
the Church.

div.head: TRIPPING THE LIGHT FANTASTIC
(Consisting of a critical analysis of the positions most commonly used therein)
div.p:
fancy "D"Dancing is a great American sport. It provides
entertainment not only for the people who partici-
pate bus also for those who watch. Perhaps it is
even more enjoyable to be among the watchers.

I have often wished I were an orchestra member
who could travel over the national playing for dan-
ces. Then I could observe the different positions
used in sections other than my own locality. As
it is, I shall have to content myself with a de-
tailed description of the dancing postures with
which I am familiar.

Some couples use the far-away position. It is
formed thus: The couple stand as far apart as
possible, close their eyes, reach out and grab for
each other's waist and shoulder. The results are
disastrous! There they are, dancing away- - -but
the way they look! It's as good as a movie to
watch them. About four feet apart, they struggle
to get farther apart but succeed only in making
certain parts of their anatomy protrude in a very
undignified manner. This version of the dance is
very common.

There is also the "cuddle-up" position which
is usually practisedpracticed by c.f.'s ("educated foxes,"
more commonly known as "wolves.") This is just
the opposite of the far-away position. The man
tries to choke the girl, while she, not to be out-
done, proves her possession of a superwoman grip
by clutching his shoulder tightly. Instead of im-
pressing the innocent by-stander with the beauty
11
The Nebraskanette 12
of their passion, they seem to be in the throes of
a violent antipathy. Perhaps they believe their
attitude appears to be that of lovers- -but oh,
brother!

Dancing on one's feet is a good idea. So many
people seem to do it. However, dancing on someone
else's feet is also a very common practice. The
latter is not particularly popular with the person
to whom the feet belong. For some reason, each
individual likes to dance on his own feet, but
does not care to have others dance on them as
well.

In order to avoid stepping on other dancers'
feet, many participants in the sport take long,
sweeping steps. They may think they look graceful,
but they really resemble nothing so much as assor-
ted ostriches walking about the dance floor. This
method usually eliminates the problem of stepping
on people's feet, but who wants to look like an
ostrich?

One frequently meets the boy who is obviously
doing a dance of duty. His mouth is set in a firm,
unpleasant line; and, frowning menacingly at one
and all, he pushes his unhappy partner around the
floor as if she wore a sack of meal.

Then there is the couple who seem utterly ob-
livious to everything and everyone around them.
As they gaze soulfully at each other, their eyes
gradually droop shut, and they imagine themselves
in Heaven. The other dancers express their dis-
approval by frowning and muttering. Finally, the
"out of this world" couple are brought rudely back
to earth by a series of bumps and collisions. Does
this bother them? On, no! They dance ahead as if
there had been no interruption. At least the other
dancers retire and watch them as they drift
through dreamland. The floor is theirs, and they
use it, too.

The show-off couple can be found upon any dance
floor. Their main purpose is to be outlandish and
different. They will dance in any way in order to
make themselves the center of attention. They
will execute rapid turns, hop, jump, or even turn
somersaults in order to be the chief attraction.
This mode of dancing is commonly called "jitter-
bugging."

Yes, dancing is fun; but it's better than a
three-ring circus to watch other people trip the
light fantastic.

figure.figDesc: A hand drawn face appearing to be black

div.head: NEGROES AND WHITES

figure.figDesc: A hand drawn face appearing to be white

div.p:
fancy "I"I used to look at a negro as a person who was
sort of dirty and dangerous because I lived in the
South a great deal of my life-time. Where I lived
a white man who killed a negro was put in one night
and let out the next morning, but if a negro killed
a white, the negro was put to death immediately.

Down South a negro has his own school, his own
church and his own side of the railroad track; but
here they sometimes go to school with whites.
For example: the other day I saw two girls walk-
ing down the road from school. They were about
six and four, the older a negro, the younger a
white. They had their arms around each other like
a pair of sisters. Down south if a white mother
saw this she probably would have had the negro's
parents put in jail, which is very easy to do. I
think, if we would not curse the negroes so much
and let them be more like us, we would have much
better luck with them. I think there would be
fewer fights and killings. When I get on a bus
lots of times I see a negro in one corner all by
The Nebraskanette 14
himself. The whites won't sit by him at all.
They act as if they are better than he is.

I had a very good friend once, a man about fifty
years old. He was a negro. He liked me very much
and would do almost anything for me. Some negroes
are all right but others are just born with crook-
edness. We had negroes working for us who had all
come down in a truck from Austin or Houston. The
whites just haul them around in trucks like horses.
Wherever the driver of the truck takes them that's
where they go. They live in tents, caves or right
out in the open with only a couple of blankets.
Their usual work is in the cotton fields, hoeing
or picking.
I think we should treat the negroes better.

div.head: MY HOME
div.p:
fancy "M"My home, the State Home for Dependent Children,
is located at University Place, 5903 Walker Avenue.

Several years ago the home of Mr. and Mrs. C.
C. White was bought by the State for $32,000. Be-
fore this time the State Home was located on
twelfth street. Since White Hall was purchased
the State has added five different main buildings.
Now most of the children are located on the
grounds.

White Hall is the main building. Here are lo-
cated the main offices and employees' kitchen and
dining room. On the third floor of White Hall the
senior girls and I live. Here are also the super-
intendent's apartment and welfare workers' offices.

Next is the girls' Training Cottage. The Cot-
tage is a large two story white house where girls
stay for training when they become twelve years
old.

At the cottage the girls learn to cook, sew,
and clean. After they are fourteen to fifteen
years old, they go to White Hall. In the basement
of the Cottage the fifth and sixth grade have
their school room.

Benson Hall is named after Mrs. Benson who was
a chairman of the Board of Control. It consists
of the main kitchen and dining room in the base-
ment, the first and second nerserynursery on the first floor
and the clinic room or doctors' offices. The sec-
ond floor is where the smaller girls have their
department. The third floor has a dentist's room
and a hospital where all the children are isolated
when they first come into the institution before
they are put in a department.

On the east side the boys have their department.
In the basement of this building the first four
grades have their school room. On the first and
second floor the small boys from four to nine also
the large boys from nine to fourteen have their
department here. The third floor consists of rooms
for employees.

Besides these main buildings we have a large
garage, a laundry and a school house for sixth to
eighth grade. During the past two years we have
added two new building, one by the school for re-
creation or play and then we completed late this
fall a large cave to store our canned fruit and
vegetables, potatoes, cabbage, etc., we raised
in the summer.

Then out two miles we have a farm for boys from
fourteen to eighteen.

The boys have a man and wife to take care of
them. They help put in the crops and harvest them,
do the house cleaning, chores, get meals, and do
the dishes.

They get up around 5:30 or 6:00 and go to bed
at 8:30 or 9:00.

Mrs. Mouden, our superintendent, also bought
the farm since she has been at the home.

We also have the first nursery and second nur-
sery. In the first nursery the babies are from
three weeks to two years old. After they leave
the first nursery they go to the second nursery
where they stay from two years to four or five
years, when the girls go to Benson Hall and the
boys to West Side or Hager Hall.

At the home we have seventy-two employees at
the present time. That includes the file clerk,
bookkeeper, and superintendent and stenographers.

We also have plenty of entertainment; we always
have parties and mixers. We always celebrate the
fourthFourthof July and all other holidays. In the
fall we go to the Circus and State Fair.

Well this is about all I can say, so I'll quit
by saying that I am proud of my home.

div.head: JAZZ MANIACS
div.p:
fancy "H"Have you ever met a maniac; a jazz maniac, I
mean? They are the people who think sharps, and
dance flats. All they ever think of is music.
Don't get my wrong, I like music, and jazz, but
not this type.

At a dance you're dancing peacefully with a
girl when somebody stops the victrola and puts on
a music plate he brought from home. Out of this
record comes forth sounds as though the roof were
falling in.

Two wierdly-cladweirdly-clad figures, maniacs, in other
words, jump on to the floor, and start hitting
each other over the head. Then they start some
very interesting aerobatics. He grabs her, she
Sleep 17
grabs him. Wham! Big fight! They call that dan-
cing. When the music stops, they drag each other
off the floor and congratulate themselves on what
a swell dance they had.

You start dancing again, when who should heave
into view but our bouncing buddies. They jazz to
a waltz.

After throwing you off the floor, our maniacs
do a series of wiggles that would make Houdini
crawl.

Now that I've given you a general description
of their dancing technique, let me show you how
they talk.

He: "How about bashin' the bundle with me,
bee?"
Silly, isn't it?

She: "Not 'til you perambulate around to the
glass gaze and slick down your mop."

Did you ever hear such stuff? I didn't until
then.

I asked a friend of mine, who is one of those
moon gazers, to go to a psychiatrist, but he re-
fused.

There's not much more to say on the topic ex-
cept that the maniac piles his home full of re-
cords of every type and description. He treasures
each one more than the next and will murder you if
you break one of the million.
So, for quieter living, don't go near one.

div.head: ICE SKATING OR OTHERWISE
div.p:
fancy "B"Being of sound mind (?) and body, I hereby be-
queath- - - - -sounds rather pessimistic doesn't it?
Well, the ice skating season is here again and I
shall soon be making my yearly attempt to learn to
ice skate. Therefore, before I start out, I feel
a will might be a very good idea.

Ice skating can truly be an art, when it is
done properly. It is a demonstration of true
grace and beauty, however, my skating is not an
example of either one.

The first time I went ice skating, I started
out with high hopes; after all, it looks so simple.
First, I put on my skates- -well that was easy any-
way- -then I proceeded to attempt to stand up.
After a fierce battle to get my skates to stop
wobbling and actually get my balance, I started
out. My skates seemed to have a difference of
opinion concerning the direction I was going and I
sat down, not very gently, I might add.

figure.figDesc: hand-drawn pencil-shaded girl on ice skates with her hair down. She's wearing a dress.

div.p:
Why something which looks so simple
should be so arduous I will never
understand. The fight those two little
skates can put up never ceases to amaze
me.

My patience is wearing thin in the
face of so many defeats, so if you see
me starting out with a pair of ice
skates and a "do or die" expression in
my eyes, don't be alarmed, I won't kill
anyone, at least not intentionally, I
merely wish to learn to ice skate.

div.head: THREE GREAT DOCUMENTS IN THEHISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES
div.p:
fancy "T"The Declaration of Independence announced the
freedom of the Thirteen Colonies from Great
Britain. Thomas Jefferson was responsible for the
drafting of the Declaration of Independence. Many
phrases were dropped from his original copy by
Congress. One of the most important of these was
the clause which abolished slavery in the United
States. The Southern Congressmen wouldn't let
this issue pass and it was therefore taken away
from the document.

The Congress studied the document on the sec-
ond, third, and fourth of July. It was signed late
in the afternoon on July 4, 1776. It was read
publicly on the following Monday.

The document accuses the king of trespassing up-
on the rights of the people. It declares all men
equal and acknowledges the right of everyone to
life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.

The states had now thrown off the British yoke
and stood without a government to hold them to-
gether.

The Articles of Confederation was the next step
in the forming of our great nation. The same day
the Continental Congress ordered a committee to
draft the Declaration of Independence, another
group was organized to prepare the Articles of
Confederation. A month after the Declaration of
Independence had been signed, the Articles of Con-
federation were submitted to Congress for approval.
This document was subjected to debate for sixteen
months in Congress and even after being adopted by
19
20 The Nebraskanette
Congress toward the end of 1777, it was not rati-
fied until March, 1781, when the war was drawing to
a close

Franklin's plan of union of 1775 was not ac-
cepted by Albany Congress, but some of the most
important features of the two documents are iden-
tical. The Articles of Confederation provided for
a Congress in which every state was entitled to one
vote and was represented by a delegation whose
members were appointed annually as the legislature
of the state might direct and whose expenses were
paid by the state and were subject to recall. In
other words it was a council of states whose re-
presentatives has little independence of action.

Extensive powers were granted to the Congress.
It could enter into treaties, declare war or estab-
lish peace, coin money and establish post offices.
But none of these powers could be exercised with-
out consent of nine states and even if the
consent was given, there was nothing to make the
states abide by the decision of Congress.

No executive was provided for except that Con-
gress was authorized to appoint such officials as
it considered necessary to run the government.
Congress might be called upon to settle disputes
between states and establish courts for the trial
of piracy on the high seas.

The plan of government was there but it had no
force behind it. Congress might declare war, but
the states might decline to participate in it; Con-
gress might enter into treaties, but it could not
make the states live up to it. Congress could
borrow money, but it could not be sure of repaying
it; and Congress could settle disputes, but it had
no way of making the parties accept the decision.

The union was ready for a stronger constitution.
The Constitutional Convention was first called for
the purpose of amending the Articles of Confedera-
tion and there were some delegates who stayed with
Three Great Documents 21
this purpose throughout the whole convention. There
were others, however, who realized that the Arti-
cles of Confederation were not satisfactory no nomat-
terno mat-
ter how changed they might become.

The Constitutional Convention which met in
Philadelphia in 1787 was the most important con-
vention everyever held in the United States. The Con-
federation under the Articles of Confederation was
a failure and if the new nation was to be justi-
fied in the eyes of the world, it must show itself
capable of effective union. This ConventionandConvention and
its outcome would mark a turning point in the his-
tory of the world and all men presentwerepresent were affected
by the importance of the task before them.

All sessions of the Convention were held in sec-
ret. The representation was by states and the
average attendance throughout the convention was
only a little more than thirty.

George Washington was chosen as presiding offi-
cer of the Convention. PersonalityandPersonality and character
played a large part in the discussions and debates
at the Convention. In such a small group, person-
ality counted as much as weighty argument.

James Madison was, next to Washington, the most
important member of the Virginian delegation.

Gouverneur Morris and Ben Franklin were the im-
portant delegates from Pennsylvania. The first
plan proposed was the Virginia Plan which called
for a completely new government.

The principalprinciple features were the organisationorganization of
a legislature of two houses with increased powers,
the establishment of a separate executive, and the
creation of an independent judiciary.

To check this drift toward radical change, New
Jersey and Connecticut presented the New Jersey
Plan which was in sharp contrast to the Virginia
planPlan and called for only a revision of the Arti-
cles of Confederation. After a short discussion,
however, the Virginia planPlan won.

The dividing line at the Convention soon became
noticeable. It was the same one as in the Congress
of Confederation- - the line between the small states
and the large states. On July 16, the great com-
promise of the Constitution was made. There were
to be two houses in Congress. The lower with re-
presentation according to the population and the upper
with each state having two votes. After this was
accepted, the Convention proceeded rapidly and on
much hotter terms.

A committee of five was named to frame the Con-
stitution. This committee made use of the New
Jersey Plan, the Virginia Plan, the Articles of
Confederation, and for the rest it depended large-
ly upon the constitutions of the states. They
drew up the draft in ten days.

The one clause referring to Congress in the
Constitution that is the most important is found
in Article I, Section 8, part 18, which gives Con-
gress authority to make any laws it thinks are
necessary to carry on the government.

The Constitution provided for a Federal Supreme
Court to settle all matters involving the inter-
pretation of the law. The Court assumed a great
power not actually provided for in the Constitu-
tion. This was the authority to declare laws of
Congress null and void.

The Constitution also provided for the single
executive. In making the provision, the Constitu-
tion created an office which had never before been
in existence.

The constitution has an effective way of check-
ing any over ambitious president. The Congress
can overrule his veto by a two-thirds vote in both
houses.

The Constitution was unanimously accepted in
Congress and sent to the states for their approval.
The Constitution had to have nine states ratify it
before it could go into effect. Delaware was the
Who Were the Greeks? 23
first to ratify the Constitution on December 7,
1787. The others followed and the Constitution
went into effect on June 21, 1789. The other four
states accepted the Constitution later and on May
21, 1790, all Thirteen Colonies belonged to the
union.

A great experiment was made in establishing a
nation under the principalprinciple of self-government, and
the whole world anxiously awaited its success or
failure.

div.head: WHO WERE THE GREEKS?
div.p:
fancy "W"We don't know more about the origin of the Greek
people than we do about the founders of Egypt or
Babylon. Our knowledge of them begins about the
time when the Assyrians had conquered most of west-
ern Asia.

For 200 years after the time of these Oriental
monarchs, Greek life and thought blossomed out at
their best.

The ancestors of the Greeks of historic times
came south from the valley of the Danube, or pos-
sibly from the region north of the Black Sea. The
Greeks later called themselves Hellenes and their
land Hellans.

The invaders didn't come all at once but in
waves about two hundred years apart. There were
four divisions of them, the Achaeans, the Aeolians,
Ionians, and Dorians.

In about 1100 B. C. a big wave of Dorians came
into the Peloponnesus, the southern peninsula of
Greece. They drove out the people already living
there.

You would have found among the people of ancient
Greece every trait and quality that human beings
ever possessed. The Greeks were very reasonable.
24 The Nebraskanette
They took an interest in business, in commerce, in
art, in government, in philosophy, and in religion.
They were a free-minded people and didn't feel
bound by any tradition or habit. These Greeks
were also great builders. Some of the more famous
buildings that are still standing are "the Porch
of the Maidens" and "the Theseum" at Athens. On
these buildings we noticed three types of columns.
These columns were the Doric, Ionic, and the Cor-
inthian.

The Doric column was the
simplest of the three columns.
It was made more for heavy use
then were the Ionic and Corin-
thian columns. The Doric col-
umn also has no formal base
and a very simple capital.

The Ionic capital had de-
signs of scrolls on it. This
column was more slender than the Doric column.

figure.figDesc: hand-drawn representation of each of the three columns (labeled), starting with Doric, then Ionic, then Corinthian

div.p:
The most ornate of the three columns was the
Corinthian, which was used more by the Romans than
the Greeks. It is said that the artist that made
the design got the idea when he saw a basket set
on the leaves on an acanthus plant.

The Greeks were very superstitious. They
thought that all the gods lived on Mt. Olympus but
no Greek had seen, or even thought he had seen, a
god there.

They had many gods. Some of the Greek gods you
are familiar with are JupiterZeus, the king of gods;
NeptunePoseidon, god of the sea; MercuryHermes, messenger of the
gods, and many more.

The Greeks put human weakness and vices as well
as good qualities into their gods. These gods
could be jealous, deceitful, and cruel. They were
much like normal people.

The Greeks could easily be led by a smooth
talker and they were always ready to give some
Buses 25
sympathy. A hero one day was a villain the next
in Greece.

Greek life from around 1200 to 800 B. B. is
pictured in two poems written by a blind man named
Homer. These two poems were the Iliad and the
Odyssey. Every person of culture in Greece knew
these poems.

These poems tell about the latter part of the
war between the Greeks and the people of Troy
in Asia Minor (about 1194 B. B. to 1184 B. C.), and
of the experience of Odysseus on his return home
after Troy had been captured.

The people of ancient Greece were mostly farm-
ers, fishermen, or traders on the sea. Although
they made their own weapons and armor for war,
there were a few skilled tradesmen among them.

They thought that they were all descended from
a common ancestor, whom they called Hellen. All
who weren't Greeks were "Barbarians."

Some of the Greeks organized in leagues, or am-
phistyonics.

Each city was jealous of each other because it
was afraid the other might get more powerful, so
they had many wars.

One of the greatest of all unifying factors was
the Olympic Games. These were held every year at
Mt. Olympus. At these games they had many contests
of physical skills. The visitorvictor of these contests
was given a head band of olive leaves.

div.head: BUSES- -TO BE SQUASHED OR NOT TO BE SQUASHED
div.p:
fancy "U"Unfortunately I do not live at the end of the
bus line; and by the time I am ready to make my
appearance on the bus, it is fairly crowded. But
26 The Nebraskanette
wait, we haven't picked up all the other passen-
gers.

I wish the bus driver would stop telling us to
move to the back of the car. He doesn't know that
some of the passengers are halfway out of the back
of the bus. I wish this ape in front of me would
get off my foot. Maybe if I drop one of my books
he will pick it up for me and then kindly remove
his big clodhoppers. Well, here goes. "Oh, thank
you ever so much." Well, now I can uncurl my toes.
Boy what a relief!

I wonder who's pushing up in front. I wish
they would stop. Ooh, you big stiff. "No, you
didn't hurt me. Thanks, I'm quite all right and I
think I can manage to pick myself up."

I'd better grab the closest object there is,
because the bus is going to stop. "Just a minute,
driver." Gee whiz, I feel like a fool. I should
have known better than to lean against the door,
and fall out as the bus came to a stop and the
doors flew open.. Well, anyway, the people got a
good laugh out of it and I, well..........

Just three more blocks and I'll be out of this
sardine can. This time I'll make sure nothing
happens when the bus stops. Oh, golly, where's
my shoe? I know I put both of them on this morn-
ing. Jeepers, I can't go to school with just one
shoe. Why, I'll be the laughing stock of the
whole school. I must have lost it when we had
that awful lurch two blocks back. Ah, there it is
under that seat. But I can't crawl under the seat
to get it because it would look ridiculous.
"Yes, ah, that's my shoe; thank you."

At that moment I wished the ground would open
up and swallow me. Saved! The bus has stopped
and here's where I get off. I still think that
some of the most embarrassing moments can and do
take place on buses.

div.head: MACBETH BY FAIRES

figure.figDesc: hand-drawn picture of Bugs Bunny dressed as a knight and holding a carrot. It spans almost the entire height of the page.

div.p:
fancy "Y"You are about to read
a play. After you have
read it, you will wonder
why you did, but never-
theless, you are about to
read it.

There are two Macbeths.
Macbeth by Shakespeare,
and Macbeth by Faires. If
you are fool enough to
think you are about to
read the better of the
two, or anything even
closely resembled to the
better of the two, then
either you're crazy, or I
am. You don't know it
now, but in the following
lines what Faires has done
to Shakespeare, shouldn't
happen to Smoe and Kilroy
put together.

Now, if you still want
to read this thing, you
must do so at your own
risk, as we are not re-
sponsible in any way for
anything anyone might do,
after the smell has
drifted away. Remember,
the management is not re-
sponsible!!!

Any faint possible resemblance between this and
anything Mr. S. wrote is purely coincidental.

The author must also reserve the right to have
a twenty-minute head start in any direction, after
the reader has finished. . . .

div.head: A Scene from MACBETH
div.byline: by F. Faires (with a little help from Mr. S.)

p.stage:
The scene is Macbeth's Castle, a very modern
castle, as castles go. Over the door is a bright
red neon sign which flashes off and on and reads,
"Macbeth's Place, Deliveries in the Rear." Mac-
beth is one of King Duncan's best soldiers, and gets
paid very well; as a matter of fact, he has more
money than Carter's have Little Liver Pills.

As the scene opens, Duncan drives up in front
of the castle in a sixteen cylinder Buick. Duncan
is tall, dark and has a handsome bank roll. He is
about forty-five, but is still an obvious, up and
atom wolf. He climbs out of the car, and crosses
an electric eye beam, which automatically lowers
the draw bridge. He then crosses to the court yard
where he finds Lady Macbeth sipping pink lemonade,
and drooling over a picture of Van Johnson........

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p:
Hello, stranger, long time
no see!

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
I thought it was about
time for you to drop in, you wolf.

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p:
I am not a wolf! I'm just an enthusiastic
kitten.

sp.speaker: Ross:
sp.p: Did you ring for me?

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
Well, that bell didn't toll for Pino-
cicoPino-
cchio. Here, lock my Van Johnson picture in the
safe.

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p:
It's so lonesome being king all by myself,
why don't you jump in your airplane and come up
and see me sometime?

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p: What? And leave Macbeth here alone?

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p: Oh, what do you care for that drip???

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
Be quiet Duncan. After all he's
one of the best husbands I ever had.

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p:
So this is what goes on when my back is
turned. Duncan, I told you not to come here!

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p:
I can come here if I want! After all, I'm
still king.

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p: That settles it! I'm going home to father!

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p:
But you can't do that, I need you in the
army.

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p: I can if I want!

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p: Over my dead body!

p.stage: (Macbeth takes out a gun and shoots Duncan.)

sp.speaker: Duncan:
sp.p:
All right, go home to your old
father, see if I care!

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
Now just look what you've done. He
flopped over on my very best rose bush.

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p:
I'm sorry, remind me to be more careful
next time.

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
Say, do you know that this leaves
the way open for you to be king???

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p:
I hadn't thought of that. Being king
would be nice.

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
Who knows, if we keep this up, we
might even move to Chicago. You could hold
people up, and I could shop lift.

sp.speaker: Ross:
sp.p: Banquo is here.

p.stage: (Enter Banquo and looks at the body.)

sp.speaker: Banquo:
sp.p:
My, my! The king is murdered, what a pity!
That reminds me, read any good books lately????

sp.speaker: Ross:
sp.p:
Never mind. Who's going to tell Malcom
about this????

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p:
Oh dear. I forgot about him. I don't
30 The Nebraskanette
suppose he'll like this very well, will he?????

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p: I don't suppose.

sp.speaker: Banquo:
sp.p: Oh, I just love gossip! I'll run and tell him

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p: Now what will I do???

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p: We're in a jam!

sp.speaker: Ross:
sp.p: There's the door bell. I'll answer it.

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p: Well, who is it???

sp.speaker: Ross:
sp.p: It's Malcom and.......

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p: My, he got here fast didn't he????

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p: Oh they can do anything like that in these plays.

sp.speaker: Ross:
sp.p: He says he wants to cut your head off!

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p:
Well, tell him to come right in...WHAT??
My head??? Oh dear, oh dear, what will I do?
Hide me someone!

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p: I think I'll kill myself!

sp.speaker: Ross:
sp.p:
Hold everything! A letter just came for
Lady Macbeth.

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
Quick! Pack your
suitcase and we'll slip out the back way. "We'll
have to hurry to catch the next train!

sp.speaker: Macbeth:
sp.p: But where can we go????

sp.speaker: Lady Macbeth:
sp.p:
To Hollywood. M.G.M. wants you to
play stand-in for Boris Karloff.

sp.speaker: All:
sp.p: Success at last! Crime pays!

div.head: OLD FRIENDS OF THE FAMILY
div.p:
fancy "T"They ought to be put behind bars. They ought
to be taken before a court and convicted. These
people who make unexpected visits are real crimi-
nals! They burst in when you don't want to see
anyone, especially not them. It would seem in-
Old Friends of the Family 31
credible if they came when a person had the time
and inclination to entertain them.

It seems to be a joyous time for everyone but
me when these old friends pop in. Everyone else
appears to enjoy himself.

Seldom do they have any important purpose in
coming, but regardless, I have to appear extremely
hospitable when I am introduced. They always say,
"My dear," or "Why, the last time I saw you, you
were only this high." These platitudes revolt me
no end. I can't remember whether I had ever seen
them or not.

When they arrive, they usually let it be known
that they can stay only fifteen or twenty minutes,
but these fifteen or twenty minutes develop into
hours. My mother urges them to stay for dinner,
and they accept her invitation very willingly. My
heart sinks into my shoes when I have to be the
"aide de camp" in the kitchen, which ruins my
evening plans to go to the basketball game.

My heart drops still deeper when Mother invites
them to stay all night and take the noon train the
following day. The last straw is their acceptance
to stay. My room is transformed immediately into
a guest room and I spend the night on the daven-
port.

By morning, I have a still neck and an extremely
wicked attitude toward old friends of the family.

By the time the breakfast dishes are done, I
start trying to get our guests off so there will
be no danger of their missing the noon train.

The goodbyes are long and sorrowful affairs for
everyone except me. As I watch, beaming secretly
to myself, I notice a cobweb forming in the door-
way.

Finally, they walk down the sidewalk and I give
a sigh of relief for I am always happy when
people leave after such visitations. Such people
need to do more reading in etiquette books.

div.head: HISTORY OF ALGEBRA
div.p:
fancy "H"History has two definitions. One, it is
everything that happened in the past; the second,
it is a written record of special things which
happened in the past. As an algebra student, I
shall tell you what I know about the history of
algebra in each of these ways.

figure.figDesc: hand-drawn picture of an Egyptian man with a tablet and question marks above his head. The tablet has equations written on it. The figure is centered mostly in the middle of the second paragraph, centered on the page.

div.p:
First, there is everything
that happened to algebra in
the past. Al-gebra is said
to have been started in
Egypt, as many geometric and
algebraic prog-ressions were
found in their ancient papers.
In Greece, al-gebra was writ-
ten in geomet-ric forms, and
verbal problems which are the
basis of those used in our
books today, were worked.
Diophantus com-piled the alge-
braic knowledge of the Greeks
into one volume. In this book, he made a great
contribution by using symbols for unknown quantit-
ies and powers. He spent most of his time study-
ing problems in which the solution was indetermin-
ate. Hypatia, the first known woman mathemeticianmathematician
wrote many commentaries on the works of Diophantus
and she followed his theories. In India, the
Hindus were interested in series, and linear and
quadratic equations. In the twelfth century,
Europe became interested in algebra and two men
were brought to Frederick II, where they had a
32
Perfume and the Ladies (and the Men) 33
mathematical tournament. In this tournament,
Fibonacci added to his prestige as a genius in
algebraic analysis. Gradually, algebra spread
throughout the world as a common study of
mathematics.

Second, the written record of the common pu-
pil's algebra that has happened in the past is:
Hurrah! I passed!!

div.head: PERFUME AND THE LADIES (AND THE MEN)
div.p:
fancy "P"Perfume, according to Webster, is "a substance
that emits an agreeable odor." It is generally
known that this substance which emits such an
agreeable odor is usually a young lady wearing some
one of over one hundred thousand different kinds
of perfumes.

The purpose of perfume is to allure. (That's
what I hear, anyway.) Many a lass has found per-
fume to be her answer in enticing a man.

There are over one hundred thousand different
kinds of perfumes. They can be roughly classified
into two groups: the potent and the non-potent.
The average young lady has several kinds of non-
potent perfumes sitting around on the top of her
dressing table, but now and then we run across
someone who is wearing a potent perfume. The
effect is flooring.

What is a woman without perfume? Perfume is the
whipped cream on her ginger-bread, the a-la on her
34 The Nebraskanette
a-la-mode, the cherry on her sundae, the sugar in
her coffee, and the butter on her toast.

Have you read the latest perfume ads? If not,
you have no idea what perfume means to modern
misses. Perfume is....."the lilting, lingering,
loveliness....for you alone! Elusive....provoca-
tive....tantalizingly unforgettable, intriguing as
the lengthening shadows of twilight,....stirring as
that first star-canopied moment alone! The frag-
rance that weaves a subtle spell and softly whis-
pers 'you'."

Perfume, the magazine ads try to imply, can
seemingly transform a woman into almost anything.
She is either "a heaven-sent angel," "a white
flame," "devastating," or a "beau catcher." These
perfumes are supposed to have quite an effect on
the men, as their names imply. Actually, I don't
think men pay the least attention to the perfume
women wear unless it is some of the more potent
type. This potent perfume bears a striking resem-
blance to any delousing fluid.

If the modern maiden wishes to inspire jealousy,
all she does is don some "Jealousy" perfume. If
the young lady wants to be devasting, all she has
to do is put a drop of perfume behind each ear and
(as the perfume ads claim) she will become as dev-
astating as her hat. And oh! what a hat!

We of the masculine sex do not realize what per-
fume means to the ladies. As some perfume ads put
it: "a perfume made of all the things you love,"
or "Adventure, mixed with mystery, gay and lilting
as ballet music."

Why don't girls wear perfumes called "caramel,"
"butterscotch," "apple pie," or "chocolate," in-
stead of the fumes called "Indifference," or "An-
nihilation"?

Remember boys, as Kipling once said it, "The
female of the species is more deadly than the
male!"

div.head: ONE TOO MANY SISTERS

figure.figDesc: hand-drawn pictures of an older girl looking angrily at a yonger girl (presumedly her sister) reading a diary. There is a lamp next to them at the table that the younger girl is sitting at. The picture is left aligned in primarily the first paragraph.

div.p:
fancy "L"Little brothers- -ugh!
- -many times I have heard
them spoken of in just
that way- -brothers! Some
even hold contempt for
them in their voices- -
brothers! Well, what
about sisters? Doesn't
anyone ever have an onery
sister, a mean little
sister? Well, let me tell
you about mine.

My sister's name is
Georgia Ann and she is 13
years old. She is as tall
as I am and probably will turn out to be a taller
person. I might say she was tall for her age, but
compared to some of the young giants in her grade,
she is a "pip-squeak."

Her disposition is variable. The only way I
can describe it is by quoting a nursery rhyme.
"When she is good, she is very, very good...when
she is bad, she is horrid." As I write more you
will get the general idea.

The biggest problem in our life is the problem
of sharing. Now that she is "growing up," she
thinks she can get certain compensations, things
like getting out of the housework that she never
really helped with anyway- - -.

I'm going to ask a question. Would I have to
share my bedroom if she worewere a brother? Now I'll
35
36 The Nebraskanette
answer it. Most certainly not!! If she were a
brother I would have a room all by myself. Oh,
happy day, what a glorious thought.

Connected with this thought is another- - - I
would so much like having a closet of my own.
Really, I would. It would be worlds simpler but,
no, she's a sister and sisters share.

My bicycle is a much disputed matter. When it
was new, it was given to me. Georgia was small
then but in the last few years she has learned how
to ride. Now the bicycle is jointly owned and
mostly by the little "joint." (She thinks.)

She is growing up; that I can't deny, but she
just popped up. A year ago she couldn't being to
wear my clothes. Now they fit her better than they
do me.

It had been a hard and fast rule at our home
that the girls, meaning Georgia and I, should not
wear each other's clothes. Of course, that's all
changed; now the rule is if you see anything you
like, grab it and run! No, it's really not quite
so bad. Only once in a while does she wear my
stuff and then only with my permission.

Can someone tell me what is the proper time
for a thirteen-year-old to go to bed? Georgia's
motto is, "Don't go to bed until you just can't
stand up any more and then if possibly hold out
just a little bit longer." Then, when she goes to
bed, she wants me to follow directly. Well, some-
times I'm willing, but other times it's almost im-
possible. Of course, that's my story and we won't
go into that.

Who does the dishes? A problem in every home
is who does the dishes? My sister argues, "Let
Bobby do them; she's older and the older ones help
more." My argument is "Let Georgia help; she's
younger and should have to do things like that."
Oh well, you can't win, so why try?

I have a suggestion to make to the Journal
company. Why don't they send two papers to us in-
stead of one? It would simplify life so much.
When we hear the paper hit the porch, we start in
our fifty-yard dash. The lucky one gets it, the
other one usually gets a banged head or a skinned
knee. "Why shouldn't I get the evening paper first;
I'm the younger." As I said before, you can't win.

But, all in all, everything included, she's
not so bad. Sisters, in general, all have their
good points. Their companionship is something to
treasure. Their help with the work is good, when
you can get it.

My sister's personality is developing more
every day. She is getting a fine sense of humor.
It's only once in a while that something gets
under her skin. As she is getting older, she is
getting more sensible and dependable. That is
something fine to see.

I don't want anyone to get me wrong. I love
my sister and I wouldn't change her for a million
like her, but sometimes she gets under my skin and
this is the only way I can think of to get rid of
it. Oh well, that's life.

div.head: I'LL BE HOME FOR CHRISTMAS
div.p:
"I'll be home for Christmas," the song sand
from under Diane's fingers as she played the piano.
There was a large tree at one end of the room
beautifully decorated with colored balls, tinsel,
Santa Claus, angels, and a huge silver star at the
top. Near by was the fire-place with holly and
candles on it. This room, the snow falling lazily
outside, the fire in the fire-place brought back
memories- -memories of her brother Cal.

The last time Cal was in this room was three
years ago. He sang songs, he joked, and he popped
popcorn but- -Cal would never do those things again.
Cal was dead, killed at Salerno..

Diane remembered the times Cal played football,
even got his nose broken once. Gosh, he looked
funny with that big bandage on his face. There
was the time he swam at Crow Lake and got sun-
burned. He looked like a beet! Cal sang in the
Church choir; he was there every Sunday. Diane
thought of the many girls in Cal's life. Marge,
Georgia, Sally, Shirley, and the last one was
Carol; he had loved them all. He loved this room,
he loved Christmas, he loved everything it stood
for, the birth of Jesus, the manger, and the glory
of giving gifts.

Cal will never be here for Christmas again;
he'll never sit down to a huge dinner with all the
trimmings, of turkey, potatoes and gravy, cranber-
ries, jellies, salads, nuts, candies, and mince
pie. Diane thought of the family sitting down to
the table with that missing face. Cal always sat
next to her, kidding her, and telling her not to
eat too much.

Cal will never be home for another Christmas,
he died so that we all might enjoy a free one.
Yes, Cal is dead, but Diane silently thanked God
for Cal and the other boys who died for- -Christmas.

div.head: THE CORN COB
div.p:
fancy "W"Well, Old Man Winter is a-whirlin' 'round the
house again, and January is full force! January,
that's the month that everybody has to pay the
bills for the fun they had in December. Also the
month that everybody breaks the New Year's resolu-
tions they didn't intend to keep, anyway!

So, slither into your rocking chairs and pull
The Corn Cob 39
out your knitting, 'cause you want to be sure and
not miss this month's little bits of "ha! ha!"
Lend an ear, kiddies, - - - - - - - - -

sp.speaker: Doctor:
sp.p:
Great heavens! Who stuffed that towel in
the patient's mouth??

sp.speaker: Kilroy:
sp.p:
I did, Doc. You said to main thing was
to keep her quiet!

div.p: Dear Tom:

Come over tomorrow evening. Papa is at home,
but he is laid up with a very sore foot. See?
Love,
Mary
Dear Mary:

I can't come over tomorrow evening. I'm laid
up on account of your father's sore foot. See?
Love,
Tom

The man called up the doctor and said, "I want
you to come over right away! The baby has just
swallowed my fountain pen!"

"I'll be over right away," replied the doctor.
"Meanwhile, what are you doing?????"

"Oh," replied the gentleman, "I'm using a lead
pencil!!"

sp.speaker: Golsby:
sp.p:
"Did anyone in your family ever make a
brilliant marriage???"

sp.speaker: Harry:
sp.p: "Only my wife!"

sp.speaker: First Camper:
sp.p: "O-U-C-H!"

sp.speaker: Second Camper:
sp.p: "Wazzamatta????"

sp.speaker: First Camper:
sp.p: "I just found the needle!"

div.p:
A colored soldier had been peeling potatoes
until his hands ached. Turning to a fellow K. P.
he said, "What dat sergeant mean when he call us
K. P.?????"

"Ah dunno," replied he co-worker. "But from
de look on his face, ah figures he dun meant,
'Keep Peelin'."

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p:
"John, there's a burglar in the silver and
another in the pantry eating my pies. Get up and
call for help!

sp.speaker: John:
sp.p:
"Help! Help! Send the
police! Better send a doctor, too!!!!!"

sp.speaker: Sentry:
sp.p: "Halt! Who goes there???"

sp.speaker: Voice in the dark:
sp.p: "An American."

sp.speaker: Sentry:
sp.p:
"Oh, is that so! Advance and recite the
second verse of "The Star-Spangled Banner.'"

sp.speaker: Voice in the dark:
sp.p: "I don't know it!"

sp.speaker: Sentry:
sp.p: "Pass, American!"

sp.speaker: Spinster:
sp.p:
"So the waiter said to me, 'How would
you like your rice???'"

sp.speaker: Friend:
sp.p: "Yes! Yes! Go on, dearie."

sp.speaker: Spinster:
sp.p: "So I said wistfully, 'Thrown at me!'"

div.p:
Now that you've lent your ear, you can have it
back again. I could tell you about a "chuck" be-
ing a Shakespearean term meaning chicken, but I
won't. That's because that mean A. Flood beat me
to it in that Katty Kolumn of her.. (Gerrrrrrr!)
- -See December issue.

Well drown me in alcohol, and call me pickled,
if it isn't time to run along. So, until next time
I'll say in Spanish (???) "hasty lumbago" which
means, goo-by, and I do mean goo! Frank Faires

div.head: HOW MANGE AGES...
div.p:
fancy IIf one could imagine himself as standing on a
lofty peak from which he could witness the
panorama of life through the ages spread out
before him how struggling, how foolish our
twentieth century existence would seem! How
unimportant the mere four or five thousand years
of our civilization would be! For the vastness of
time is almost beyond human comprehension. No one
as yet can accurately tell how long our earth, our
universe, and the seemingly limitless regions of
the heavens beyond have existed. Henrik Van Loon
illustrated the immensity of time in this story:
"Picture a rock a hundred miles high and a hundred
miles wide. To this rock a little bird comes
every thousand years to sharpen his beak. When
the rock is completely worn away one day of
eternity will have passed."

Somewhere 'way back in that dark abyss of time
our planet was crested and the stage was set for
life to begin, for the slow ascent of man. We are
thus far on our journey and we do not know why we
are here or where we are going. We are endowed
with a world of great beauty and tremendous
capabilities. Often it looks as if we are at a
stand-still or sliding back a little for we
brutally murder our fellow men at too short
intervals and spend a great part of our energies
devising more efficient or larger scale methods of
warfare. Look back for a moment and see how little
in the chronicles of Father Time, yet how much
from our own vantage point, we have progressed.

The Darwinian theory traces the development of
man from the simplest forms of life (like jelly-
fish) to his present state. It is only a theory,
there is no proof; what remains is that man was a
special creation with a soul and the ability to
use his brain. In this way he was very different
from all other living things and that is why we
study human history instead of the history of cats
or dogs.

The common conception of prehistoric man is
some long-armed, bent-kneed, gorilla-like creature
racing through the forest dragging his wife behind
him by her hair just letting her bump along if she
can't keep up.

Such an impression is greatly exaggerated. We
know practically nothing about early man and his
origin but from discoveries of bones buried in
ancient soils, rude stone weapons, and pictures on
the walls of long forgotten caves, scientists have
pieced together a pictures of man's early existence.

According to our present standards the first
man was far from handsome, although he probably
didn't think so. He was considerably shorter
than we; he had a massive protruding jaw, a
sloping forehead, and a monkey-like face.

Early man didn't have to worry about income tax
or getting the car fixed but he was constantly
running for his very life with some angry mammoth
or a pack of wild boars hot on his heels.

Food was the prime objective in life and he
spent most of his day prowling for something to
eat. However, food was hard to obtain and not
very appetizing when one did get it. The menu for
today might have included raw leaves, the roots of
plants, raw eggs, or, if hunting had been favorable
perhaps a wild bird or a small rabbit. Nothing
was cooked of course for primitive man had not
seen fire except maybe from a volcano and if he
did see a volcano he more than likely didn't waste
Macbeth 43
any time finding a place to hide from it. He tore
at his food with his teeth like an animal, but
people were not particular about manners in those
days, the main thing was to eat.

He didn't worry about clothes, but suffered
the intense cold of winter and the blazing heat of
summer as best he could.

The day held terrors but when evening came, man
huddled fearfully in some cave or hollow tree.
The danger of the fierce animals of the night was
no trivial matter and the law was "Eat or be
eaten."

Life was full of fear and misery and yet man
has survived hunger, cold, disease, and the slow
ascent goes on.

"How many ages in time, no one knows the
rhyme." So goes an old nursery song.. The drama
of life will continue on into the ages to come
with man struggling onward to some final goal.

lg.l: He'd been willing to give his life,
But now that the war was over
He was returning to his wife.
As he came slowly over the hill,
You're going to be a king."
I've just come back from battle,
But as he thought about it
Why not? I'd just as well!"
He told his wife about it.
She thought the idea was keen.
"If he becomes a king," she thought,
She raced around like a madman,
The king was on his way,
And she didn't have much time.
She planned to stew his waiters,
And after stabbing the sleeping king
With them she'd leave the dagger.
Well, here the story gets so messed up
'Cause while the murder is going on
Your guess is just as good as mine,
Macduff was to call for Duncan,
As he came up near the bed
He saw that Duncan was "out cold,"
In fact, that he was dead.
And just to show you how sin does grow
And to cover up his wickedness
Macbeth, afraid he'd be found out,
He hired two murderers to do it,
So it wouldn't get his coat,
They caught him on the way to the castle
He went again to the witches
That said, "Take it easy my friend,
For no one born of woman
Can bring your life to an end."
The third was a crowned child
That really did him some good.
It told him he'd be a ruler
The fourth came up with a list
And read off a string of names,
It named the rulers of Scotland
Way down to the reign of James.
So he went to Macduff's castle
And killed his kids and wife.
It knocked him flat on the floor.
She talked so much to herself
Just to top it all out.
To make this story short and sweet
Maybe this is hard to follow,
But my "linguo" is easier to understand

div.head: THE DREAM COMES TRUE
div.p:
fancy "G"Gail glanced up to see Ron's smiling face. So
many thoughts sprang to her mind. Thoughts that
went way back to his football days at school. He
had been so proud because he had been the star
player on his team. After he had graduated, he had
decided to join the Navy. Then he had been sent
across and after three years he had come home
again.

It had been a long day, the day Ron came home.
Everyone tried to do and say the right things. It
was hard to know what to say for Ron had come home
blind. Gail had marvelledmarveled at the way he had kept
his chin up and smiled all the time. But now she
knew that he felt miserable inside. She had found
out just yesterday. Ron had been sitting in the
living room. The radio had been on and the
announcer was telling about a star football
player and the games he was playing in. Ron
suddenly jumped up, turned off the radio and made
his way the best he could from the room.

Gail glanced at Ron again. He was smiling as
he listened to the comedy play on the radio. "Oh
why can't he be made to see?" She shut her eyes
and kept repeating to herself, "Please make him
see again, please." Gail couldn't sit and watch
him any longer so she went up to bed.

Sleep slowly overtook her and she fell asleep
to dream. She heard music, sweet bell-like music.
It came from the stars in the sky. The music
became louder and Ron appeared. He was in his
football suit and carried his football in his hand.
A bright star shone on his face and she could see
that he could see again. A voice softly said, "He
shall see."

"He can see, he can see," she cried. Then
suddenly she awoke. She could hear her mother
saying, "My son, oh my son."

She jumped out of bed and hurried down stairs.
Ron was smiling. His eyes were half opened. He
didn't say anything but just stood there smiling.
Then she remembered what the doctor had said.
They were to call him right away if anything
happened. She knew her mother was much too happy
to remember to do it, so she walked quietly to the
phone and called him.

Both Ron and her mother were standing there in
a daze when Dr. Green came. When Ron saw the
doctor, he became filled with silence as the
doctor analyzed the case. He looked up. "It's
amazing, the object has moved to such a position
that we can safely operate."

figure.figDesc: hand-drawn boy in overalls, a long-sleeve shirt, shoes, and a hat, holding a round object with lines on it. The object looks somewhat like a basketball.

div.p:
Gail and her mother sat in the waiting room.
Neither had much to say to each
other. Soon the doctor came out.
His eyes were filled with won-
derment. He did not speak by
they knew by the light in his eyes
and the way he smiled, that it
had been a success.

div.head: Notes
div.note: Note 1: Willa Cather was born December 7, 1873 in Virginia; however, she and her family moved to Nebraska in 1883. Cather graduated from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln in 1895 and, during her long writing career, became well-known for her writings about pioneering Nebraska (Ahearn).

Note 2: In 1905, Nebraska "outlawed the sale, manufacture, or distribution of cigarettes and cigarette papers" ("Anti-smoking Law of 1905"). This law did not restrict the actual smoking of cigarettes and said nothing about pipe tobacco or cigars (a more "socially acceptable" option). Thus smokers still found ways to acquire cigarettes. However, in 1919, the ban was repealed and replaced with "two new cigarette laws, 'Smoking cigarettes in public eating places, penalty' and 'Advertising cigarettes, penalty'" ("Anti-smoking Law of 1905). Again, only prohibiting cigarette smoking, and not tobacco use in general. However, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln prohibited smoking on campus, regardless of the form as early as 1907 ("Smokers on the Campus"). So this commentary on boys who smoke discusses an idea that is generally permitted, though technically not allowed at their school, which was located on the University of Nebraska-Lincoln's campus.

Note 3: Youth Week was sponsored by the United Christian Youth Movement, as noted in the author's text. The United Christian Youth Movement of North America began in 1934 (Leffler & Bond). According to a 1948 newspaper, it was under the supervision of the International Council of Religious Education (Venable). The United Christian Youth Movement sponsored many conferences for youth that sought to correct perceived societal ills such as race tension and poor leadership capabilities (Leffler & Bond). By 1952, the movement had switched organizational supervision to the National Council of Churches (Jameson).

Note 4: The "jitterbug" dance originated in the United States and became popular in the 1930s and 1940s. Its movements are "energetic, acrobatic, and improvisational" and can be "performed with a partner, solo, or in a line" (Stein). Its name comes from the "jerky movements" of dancers during the Prohibition who drank too much alcohol. This type of dance is most often performed with jazz and swing music that has 4/4 time, though other upbeat music such as rock'n'roll can work (Stein).

Note 5: This essay, as with many essays in this text, should be read with context. The student who wrote this work moved to Nebraska from a southern state which likely still had Jim Crow laws. As such, their previous experience with race vastly differed from their observations of racial interactions in Nebraska. Although these observations likely were not cohesive across every black/white interaction, it does bring to light that racial prejudice was slowly changing. Readers should notice that, despite comments that seem derogatory, this student's expression of ideas are fairly radical for their time.

Note 6: The Nebraska state "Home for Dependent Children" was originally established as the "Home for the Friendless" in 1881 and "took in destitute children and elderly women" (Nelson). Though established by the state legislature, it was a private organization until 1897 when it was taken over by the state (Nelson). Children who were "abandoned, neglected, or committed by the court" were "placed by the Home with adoptive or foster families" ("Youngest and...").The home regularly placed 100 or more children each year and housed between 200 and 300 children ("Youngest and..."). In 1906, the Nebraska Orthopedic Hospital took over one floor of the home. In 1909, the name changed to the "State Public School" and in 1911 to "Home for Dependent Children." With this final name change, the home was temporarily moved from the southeast corner of South and 11st Streets in Lincoln, NE to 944 H Street because the hospital took over the entire building. The home moved again in 1914 to 1425 F Street (Nelson). By 1946, it is evident that the home had moved again, this time to the address the author notes: 5903 Walker Avenue.

Note 7: Jazz is a type of music that relies heavily on improvisation. Although there is much variety in jazz, it tends to be rhythmic and include "swing" forward momentum. Jazz music often has call and repeat type sounds where one instrument might respond to another instrument's notes. Because of the personal nature of jazz, it is often emotion-filled and unique to the artist ("What is Jazz?").

Note 8: The author of this essay mixed up the Roman and Greek gods. The student likely learned about both of these civilizations around the same time in class. Since the Roman culture appropriated many of the Greek customs, including their dieties, the student likely misremembered which diety names were the Greek version and which were the Roman version. As such, they put the Roman names in their essay. The corrected Greek version are noted.

Note 9: This work is a parody of William Shakespeare's Macbeth. Macbeth is one of Shakespeare's shorter tragedies and was likely written between 1599 and 1606. The play is originally set in Scotland and follows Scottish general Macbeth as he hungers for political power. Macbeth and his wife Lady Macbeth both spiral downward as they encounter the consequences of greed ("Macbeth by William Shakespeare"). The author of this parody likely read the play in class, and then chose to create an alternate version of the text, sometimes staying close to the original and sometimes drifting away.

Note 10: "Aide de camp" means "a subordinate military or naval officer acting as a confidential assistant to a superior, usually to a general officer or admiral" ("aide-de-camp"). In the context of this text, the author is likely insinuating that she feels like her mother's subordinate who is forced to help in the kitchen, even though she'd rather not.

Note 11: Although "gay" started showing up in written psychological works in the 1940s, it wasn't until the 1970s that the word become a more common term for "a (usually male) homosexual" ("gay (adj.)"). Before it became more common to discuss sexual orientation in the 1970s, "gay" described a person who was "full of joy, merry; light-hearted, carefree" or someone who was "wanton, lewd, lascivious" ("gay (adj.)"). For this text, the meaning is likely the first archaic definition, describing a joyous or carefree feeling. For more information on the etymology of the term "gay," visit www.etymonline.com/word/gay

Note 12: Although the author states that their quote is from a nursery rhyme, the quote is actually from a Henry Wadsworth Longfellow poem entitled "There was a little girl." To read the entire short poem, visit www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44650/there-was-a-little-girl.

Note 13: In this text, "Salerno" likely refers to the Allied invasion of Italy in September 1943 during World War II. The invasion did not end well. The US army tried to time the invasion with the Italian surrender, but it did not go according to plan. The Germans quickly took control of Italy when the surrender occurred, and thus the US troops met heavy fire as they came onshore. The resulting battle was horrible. After three days, it seeme the US army was finished, but they (with help from the British) brough in technological weapons and and eventually the German army was defeated. However, this was not without heavy causalties on both sides (Citino). To read a more day-by-day narrative of the battle, visit www.nationalww2museum.org/war/articles/75-years-ago-us-invasion-italy.

Note 14: In the military, "K. P." means "Kitchen Police" or "Kitchen Patrol." This duty is often assigned to lower-ranking personnel ("KP duty"). In the context of this "joke," the racial tension between the seemingly uneducated "colored" soldiers and the implied white sergeant shows just how this "lower-ranking personnel" might have been chosen for K. P. duty.
Note 15: "A. Flood" likely refers to the author's classmate Audrey Flood, who wrote "The History of Algebra."

Note 16: Although the author states that their quote is from a nursery rhyme, the quote is actually from a Christina Rossetti poem entitled "How Many Seconds?" To read the entire poem, visit quillsliteracy.org/how-many-seconds-by-christina-rossetti-1684/.
